reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is tons of fun, highly addicting and I would have to say significantly better than Minecraft. Its much more visually pleasing and colorful, not to mention you can turn any creature in the game into your pet and harvest necessary materials from them!

So here's my Pros and Cons list:

Pros:
- Fun, easy to play, with a simple yet beautiful design.
-You can tame ANY creature in the game, assuming you can survive its onslaught.
-Tons of blocks and ores to uncover and use
-Massive worlds with seemingly endless landscapes
-Easy to get around with a map to let you know where home base is.
-Directs you to exactly where you died to retrieve items.
-Very few lapses in game play (Sinking into ground, walking through solid blocks, etc.)
-Farming is actually enjoyable and serves a purpose other than feeding the player, but gives great buffs! (Can't wait until there's more to farm! So far it's just Turnips, Lettuce, Horned Melons, Wheat, and Beeswax <-- Not a crop but VERY useful!)
-You have strong control over your world and who enters it, helps prevent griefing!
-Taming and killing certain enemies actually takes some skill and strategy (i.e. killing Warmworms and taming Keepas)
-Tons of customization of homes, blocks, buildings, etc.
-Each location has different blocks and different creatures to fight/tame, very diverse biomes!


Cons: (Mostly Early Access Issues <-- Because it's still a newer game and buggy)
-Digging takes a very long time and you don't really dig any faster with upgraded cells
-No real character customization other than changing colors.
-You have to use an Extractor to get ore... which is annoying because you have to constantly make them and you have to use an extractor to get obsidian for... a better extractor... kind of obnoxious.
-Dug holes reset (I dug a super deep mineshaft to the lava layer, logged back on and it was filled in all the way to the surface even though I still had all the items from the expedition)
-Fertilizing crops is difficult (When you right click there's a major delay before they fertilize, if they do.)
-Too many necessary blocks without sufficient space to store them (The supposedly Grand" Arctek chest holds as much as the regular model
date:
so you end up with 10+ chests for all the items you'll need for crafting later.. a little ridiculous)
-Wandering pets vanish (You have to set them to "Stay" even in a fenced in area.)
-Iron hard to find (Diamond was easier to find... diamond! Also very small veins of everything including coal makes you mine for hours with little to show.)
-Miru and Hot Foot (Hot Feet?) magically appear in your well lit mineshafts with a door on it (Miru are obnoxious creatures that blind you to make them harder to hit
recommended:
Hot Foot (Feet?) light you on fire...)
-A few surface creatures a little too overpowered (ex. Blizzard Chizzard and Boss Hogs are nearly impossible to beat/tame with anything less than Iron sword or standing on a ladder.)


There are a few bugs but it's an early access game so I can't really say much because I'm sure the devs are doing there best to fix all of them. This game is fun
hoursPlayed: highly addicting and I stand next to my high recommendation. One of the best open world sandboxes I've ever played! :)"

However, what truly sets this game apart from other sandbox-voxel games is this:  The dev's.  Creativerse is one of the few games I have played where the Dev's actively interact with the community and takes Ideas from them.   And when I say this is one of the few games ive played that have this, I mean that i've only ever played one other game with Dev's as interactive as this.  It is because of the Dev's willingness to interact and take critisicm from the players that I recommend this game.  Dev's, Do keep up the good work!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

One word comes to mind... WOW!

I've been looking at (and buying) many Early Access games on steam, most have left me with a pretty bad taste in my mouth, or in some cases the previews are better then what is actually in the E.A. Game.

This was NOT the case with Creativerse, After a marathon 16 hour first day play session with some friends this game has quickly made it's way into my top 5 games.

Take Minecraft, add better graphics, shaders, sky, and sounds, more dynamic enimies, and even passive enemies and you START to see why this game is just so great.

I'm very happy I was shown this game yesterday and given a key for it, I will surely be a loud supporter of the game from here on out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I edited a few words to put emphasis on this being my subjective impression of the game.
I'm a very discerning/demanding customer, regarding videogames. My criticism is rather too harsh, considering this is a free-to-play game. Yet, this is my honest opinion, for people who might feel like I do.

A couple of years ago, this might have been a solid game. In 2015 (almost '16) it just feels dated, unoriginal and bland to me.

Personally, I welcome that developers try to reimagine Minecraft. There's still a lot of untapped potential, many elements/features that were unpolished and limited by the hardware of ~2009. There's plenty room for significant improvements and refreshing gameplay elements.
But what I find shocking is the lack of imagination most developers are displaying through their creations. Taking the formula of Minecraft, adding more block types and simplifying the crafting process won't make me overlook the awful flaws that also made me stop playing Minecraft.
It's a bit sad that all Minecraft inspired games feel so much alike. It seems like none of the developers are even trying to rethink/reinvent the formula.

After playing about 2 hours, here are the things I believe Creativerse does better than Minecraft:

- Trees (they are bigger)

Yah...That's about it. Other nice features, like the faster movement and bigger jump heights, are enjoyable, but also make the game feel nerfed. It's just too easy to escape enemies.
The gadget for placing/removing blocks is a nice idea but in effect just adds a sci-fi flair. I didn't notice a substantial change in my gameplay experience with it.

Here are the things Creativerse does worse or as bad as Minecraft, in my opinion:
(I may have missed a lot of new features, due to my short time in-game. But I wouldn't pronlong a bad experience just for the mere hope that I suddenly start enjoying it, hours later.

- Crouching (Just like in Minecraft, it's not crouching"
date: but just moving slower. Creativerse has elements like dead hollow trees
hoursPlayed: but you can never crawl through or hide in them. Your height is always the same. This would have been obvious potential for improvement! Actual crouching/crawling could do a lot to enhance immersion or add new gameplay elements.)\n\n- Limited visibility distance (The viewing distance is even worse than in Minecraft! When you climb a mountain/hill
voteText: all you get to see as you turn to enjoy the view
helpfulPercent: is a huge vast space of empty white. I'm not sure what the exact viewing distance is
votesHelpful: but it feels like maybe 100 blocks. That is a flaw that kills a game for me
votesTotal: in 2015.)\n\n- Graphical blandness - World generation (Creativerse has a couple of biomes
votesFunny: but they hardly feel varied. When I move through Minecraft
commentsCount: I am still sometimes awed by the variety of visual impressions. Creativerse just seems "flat" in comparison. Its forests look nicer
column16: due to the much bigger trees
column17: but all other biomes can only be described as bland. If the screenshots don't excite you
column18: don't expect anything better to come.)\n\n- Empty oceans (Just like in Minecraft
column19: oceans are mostly empty. There are ocean-specific block types for harvesting
column20: but I never spotted a single creature in the water. If you're wondering how oceans could ever be interesting
column21: take a look at the game "Subnautica"
column22: available on Steam. The deep sea is a biome that should be really exciting
column23:
but I have yet to see a Minecraft-styled game that shows any care for that aspect.)

- Mind-numbing combat (Same as in Minecraft. It's the most simplified combat you could code for a first-person game. Zero originality. No noteworthy tactics. No unusual combat maneuvers. No awe inspiring animations. Only the same generic old.)

- Crafting without exploration
column26: but without using your brain for it. Whenever you collect a new resource
column27: the game gives you recipes for it. Some recipes need to be found in books. It's one of the things that made Minecraft exciting in the beginning - finding uses for new materials by experimenting. You won't get that here.)\n\n- Awkward creature design (That is an entirely subjective topic
column28: but these "animals" don't do anything to make me feel immersed. It's the contrary. I feel remotely reminded of "Ren & Stimpy" characters
column29: but the animations are just too stiff and rough. The same goofy motions over and over. The creatures never feel like anything alive
column30: but just like objects inserted to annoy or be forcefully funny. Cartoony creatures of that type can be funny if placed within a story
column31: through actions within context. In a survival game that I might play for weeks
column33: the joke ends after a few hours
column34: once I've seen all animations and actions frequently. After that time I'm left with nothing but the impression that all creatures are excessively ugly.)\n\n- Generic avatar models
column35: designed for a non-mature audience (Two kids - male and female - with generic visual design.)\n\n- Artificial intelligence (Creatures either move around in very random patterns or run directly after you
column36: when they spot you. There may be more interesting creature behaviour in caves
column37: eventually.)\n\n- Bugs (A creature hit me through walls. I was in an improvised dirt hut
column38: with no openings anywhere and got hit whenever I approached a wall. It's already a big flaw the creature even knew I was there.)\n\nCreativerse isn't bad
column40: but I just didn't spot enough originality to shake off my Minecraft weariness."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

* This textual version of the review will diverse a little bit from the video-version, since I wanted to make the video version as straightforward as possible. If you're interested in a TLDR thing, probably watch the video, otherwise scroll past it ^.^ *

https://youtu.be/wFzYplXXr0E

I will try to not to compare this game to Minecraft, or any other voxel based survival open world games, altough it is hard, since the features that the competitive games currently offer are in my opinion much larger than of this one, but this one is early access so remember, you are buying a game that is still undergoing its development and creative process.
I have owned this game for quite some time now, I have seen it buggy as hell with hardly any content and recently coming into patches that added loads of new content, craftable items, new designs and very good UI changes.

So I would like to start by saying that this game is definitely on a very good track! And that the developers definitely deserve every penny you are willing to give them for this. The game receives constant updates, it is evolving, the developers are listening to feedback and adjusting the experience to it.

Altough I do feel there is still a lot to be done. The overall experience right now is smooth and can entertain you for several hours,. There are in-game ideas that definitely add some unique thinking and provide rage-free gameplay (teleporters, death relics, etc.). As well as ideas that I can see to be used to request payment in the future (after the f2p model goes live), and I hope it will not kill the game. (task based crafting)

The task based crafting for example is a good example of a feature that does not have to fit to everyone. Having to wait for a set period of time for something to finish crafting in a queue might eventually become frustrating. I personally liked this function as it allowed me to multitask and I haven’t been bothered by it, but I can imagine it will bother some.
When it comes to creativity and the overall design of the game, I have to put my hands down, open my mouth and look around. This game feels very, very smooth, every block in the game feels like it belongs there, everything seems like it has been thought through and the colour design is amazing. I always disliked minecrafts default texture pack for being too rough and hard on the eyes, but in the case of this game, it’s a world where’d I’d love to be in person. And everything is perfectly layered, it really feels like it’s one big connected world. Going from top to the very bottom is just amazing, and the creative minds behind this game really have some imagination.

Regarding UI there have been some changes through out the development and I feel they were very good as well. I was skeptical about the UI in the past and felt like I’m a little lost in it. This cloud has been a little cleared, but I still feel a little of it floating around. I’d definitely welcome some in-game guide, more informative tooltips, or basically any other way of guiding my hand through the crafting windows and such, and once you’d get used to it, you could turn it off ofcourse. (Same goes for first game start, I’d like to see some guidance there as well)

Story-wise I feel like this is the part of the game where there’s really.. nothing. I have not included this point in the video review since I don’t feel like it’s a priority for the developers. At least I have not seen any mention about it in the forums or on the store page. There are some in-game notes to be found containing some text, but there’s nothing more to that right now. I’m don’t deliberately need a story at every cost, but it would be nice to get to know something about the world I’m getting thrusted into, since it’s very colorful and nicely done in the fist place. I know the main selling points of this games are probably elsewhere, but it’s just something I’d like to see even if it would be in a very small way.

To cut the chase I’ll say that I think the main selling points of this game are the social features and the game design. It’s incredibely easy to start a multiplayer game, takes literally one second, or the blink of an eye. That makes sharing your world with someone very easy, showcasing your builds, or just generally derping around. As I recall from other similar games, I’d have to have a dedicated server application, sometimes even venture into config files, and other necessary setting ups, which is just awful, and I’m glad this game is doing it right. By game design I mean how things look, what items you can craft, how is it concieved. The entire game has a very distinct style, it’s a mix of traditional things with modern technology and possibly a little bit of magic here and there (or at least it feels like that). This gives a sort-of-a “steam-punk” feel (altough not entirely) and I definitely like that, it’s very different to other games where it’s the same thing all over again, just with different textures.

Having said that I think that the entire game is well designed not just by the visual means, but also the progression and game mechanics design. Crafting and getting further in the game feels natural and follows a nice expanding path, while it’s most of the time very clear what you need to create next, altough when starting the game for the first time it was very unclear to me.
There are definitely bugs right now, I’ve been able to pick-up my things when still being on the death screen, I can often see through blocks, the lighting system seems very fragile, I had invisible mob attacking me and some general multiplayer issues (latency, missplacement, etc.),. But that’s all expectable right now, and I feel like it will definitely get fixed, since already a lot of bugs did get fixed.

I am going to say what I said in the video review, and that is.. If you feel like supporting the developers (whom in my opinion deserve it) definitely go for it, get the game, play it right away and address your feedback to the devs. If you feel like you can probably smash out more value and entertainement from other similar games (you are probably right) and you’re hesitating with the cash (I’m not surprised, Creativerse is not cheap) just wait and see, it can still happen that this will turn into an annoying pay2play title that will slowly die, as well as it can turn into a beautiful well balanced game (it’s heading there right now). Right now I feel it’s a little “dull” and for me it doesn’t offer that much replay value (my opinion), but I feel otherwise very positive and I can see how it will become great.


Below I’ll just put some Pros and Cons to have a brief overall review.

Pros
(+) Beautiful Visuals
(+) Easy to set up multiplayer
(+) Unique game design
(+) Natural progression
(+) Honest, fair and hard working developers
(+) Constant updates
(+) Different approach to crafting (stations, extractors, etc.)
(+) Task-based crafting (altough this might be a con for some)
(+) Progression supporting features (teleporters, etc.)

Cons
(-) Price (20 is a tad high, but its a support token)
(-) Future f2p model (might go bad)
(-) No in-game guidance system, player has to figure it out
(-) No story
(-) Bugs
(-) No linux support (Win/Mac at the moment, absolute multi-platform would be nice)


Thanks for reading/watching this, or both, also check out my channel for some more reviews if you’ve enjoyed this one and/or other gaming related content. (https://www.youtube.com/user/playintosh)

Sincerely,
Playintosh

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been intrested in this game for a while.  Played during the free week, and I really like the look of the game. A little sci-fi mixed in.

But I can't recommend the game. The jump mechanics are bouncy, annoyingly so. Over all the controls could feel a little tighter and more responsive.  Usually a 1-2 second lag on selecting items and using them.

Crafting is horrible.  Too many items required, for items that have so little durability.  1-2 hours of gathering to make an item that lasts 10 minutes.  Recipes are not given to you, you have to be luck to find some good ones.  Even then if you know how to make something you have no idea where to get the required items.

Combat is who will survive the longest.  There is no way to dodge or get out of the way, so you button mash until they are dead or you are. Healing is a pain, gather a lot of items to make a potion that barely heals.  No regen.  I found it best to just kill yourself and start off with a full bar of health.

While beautiful, and has potential. It feels like 80-90% of the game is mining rock and leaves, for the rare chance of finding that one item you need 10 of to craft the next item.  Too bad you used up all your durabilty.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Updated March 15th 2016)
This game is free, even though still in Early Access, so just give it a try yourself ;)

Is this game like Minecraft"? It's definitely inspired by it
date: but also influenced by other games like Terraria. The whole genre of 3D block-based sandbox-games has been founded by Zach(tronic)'s "Infiniminer" though
recommended: and Minecraft too is just a successor of Infiniminer anyways.\n\nCreativerse looks really nice
hoursPlayed: has a pleasant atmosphere with creative weirdly-funny creatures
voteText: a touch of SF and great music. The gaming progress in the "adventure-mode" is rather fast
helpfulPercent: crafting
votesHelpful: building and discovering the large game-worlds is fun. The starting tutorial is a rather new feature and needs a bit more love in my opinion
votesTotal: but even without it the game is easy enough to get into and won't force you to resolve to Wikis.\n\nIf you're a builder-type of player
votesFunny: then you might want to choose th "peaceful"-mode in the advanced options when creating your world. A "creative/creation-mode" is in the pipeline but not done yet (Creativerse is still in Early Access). Mind that this is an online-only-game with the advantage of enabling easy multiplayer-gaming together with (and/or against) friends.\n\nCrafting-recipes have to be unlocked one after another by taking certain blocks
commentsCount: crafting stuff and obtaining rare findings. However on your next world you can simply "carry over" the whole crafting-tree that you've already unlocked. Items or blocks cannot be transferred between worlds though. World-creators can use a number of commands to keep up law and order on their own worlds.\n\nHarvesting
column16: mining and chopping only needs one tool - or rather 6 tools of different "tiers" that will fall apart after wearing out
column17: so you'll regularly need new ones
column18: just like sword and armor too. You can tame all creatures you will come across and feed them to regularly harvest their "drops"/loot from them as livestock - or fight them alternatively. You can also grow crops
column19: cook tons of different kinds of food and claim land to protect your buildings.\n\nThere's a really large number of different building-blocks to be crafted including roofs (slopes)
column20: stairs and a bunch of furniture; plus rare ones collected from treasure chests or bought from the "store" for real money to support the otherwise free game. The store only features non-gameplay-essential blocks and blueprints for large structures that you can build together with your friends. And: nearly all blocks can be rotated into all 6 directions!\n\nLike in Terraria you can make specific creatures (and also treasure chests) spawn by creating artificial biomes. The deepest layer of all Creativerse-worlds is a vast corruption-layer (even though corruption nearly doesn't "spread" at all) and can be "purified" little by little. The game will feature NPCs and villages
column21: also ruins and the like in the future
column23: but does not yet. Character customization options and modding-options are still at their planning-stage too.\n\nThere are no typical railways (yet)
column24: but you can build a network of teleporters and also ice-slope- and/or ladder-"railroads" instead - which is just as fun. The game has a background-story that is as yet only indicated by cryptic notes that you can find and read. Environmental effects (heat
column26: corruption) are making the game positively tricky
column27: also some blocks or liquids will react to these effects and change; which will also happen when you throw certain bombs at them...\n\nThe adventure-mode is rather relaxed; you can always get your stuff back after being defeated
column28: while you'll even keep your equipment and everything that's in your action-bar. There's no "hard-mode" nor "survival-mode" (yet)
column29: eating and sleeping is not necessary
column30: but just has specific advantages; food and the like does not decay. However every creature has their unique attacks and can only be found in their specific native biomes (or can be made to spawn on specific blocks).\n\nAs the game is still in Early Access here are lots of small to large features still on the to-do-list and on wish-lists of players too of course. However the devs are known for taking player-suggestions into consideration as soon as their time and internal roadmap allows
column31: and they are planning for Creativerse to become the "ultimative sandboxgame" in time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This review is why I am unhappy with the game...

I bought this because I like games like Minecraft, Craft the World, Terraria, Starbound etc. There is no single player therefore I am reliant on my internet connection to work or be available. The unlocking crafting system wont let you skip tiers so you have to craft everything before you can get to where you want. Some of the supplies you need for the crafting are so hard to find you have to tear your world up before you can find them ie brown mushrooms or glowing mushrooms. I personally like to keep my world orderly and beautiful and tearing up the terrain because I am desperate for supplies drives me nuts trying to fix it. I would rather buy the game and then do dlc for the building packs so I can play offline instead of ingame microtransactions.  The reliance on online gaming sucks because in my area the internet comes and goes with bad weather so I have to rely on games that I can play offline or multiplayer where I can host the game and let my friends join me. I wont be reccommending this game to my friends because most if not all of them are in the same position internet wise as I am.

Not sure if they will ever support mods but I don't see how they would ever support mods that were player based and free. Pros -
Better graphics than most other games of the genre (Planet Explorers excluded imo)
Progression which most games dont have but feels like Terraria somewhat.

Cons -
In game shop
Mods will likely cost more money in the future

In the end if you wan't a upgaded Minecraft with Terraria-like progression but no creative mode, this is for you.

Where do I start...

Well, in case you couldn't tell by the pictures, it's a member of the minecraft bandwagon (not saying that's necessarily a bad thing). Except Creativerse did a few things differently.

First of all, you can't go exploring caves without running into mobs every few blocks, which wouldn't be such a big problem if weapon and armor upgrades did nothing to improve your combat skill, and the combat was very similar to melee combat in Skyrim.

Resources are sometimes difficult to identify from the plethora of seemingly useless variations of rocks (staligmights, siltstone, bedrock, etc., which could have just been considered stone") and while crafting things is not difficult or confusing

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I honestly can't wait to see how much better this game gets. Already, I prefer it to Minecraft, who I imagine will be its main competitor. The game is pretty intuitive if you've ever played anything like it, but it's cartoony charm is very unique. There's a wider variety of mobs than I usually encounter in these sort of games, and they all are needed at some point or another for crafting. Since some mobs are localized to certain biomes, theres actually an incentive to explore! In minecraft all I do is sit and build, because I don't need to do much else. But in Creativerse, in order to discover all the decorative walls I can make, I have to keep digging, keep exploring, and it has handy teleporters, beacons, and touchstones to help do so.

My only complaint is that some of the higher tier materials take quite some time to process/smelt in any quantity, and I have some concerns about the premium currency shop. However, as long as the items in the shop are purely cosmetic and offer no advantage (as many forum posts I've read have suggested is the case) I'd gladly continue you to play after release, and will likely shell out more cash to *ahem* pimp my crib. I would like to see some tweaking with some of the timers, but I can't complain too much, as they progress even if I'm offline. This makes it fairly simple to queue up high tier stuff before I log off for the night, and have all the materials ready when I decide to play the next day.

TL;DR: This game makes minecraft look bad, the devs are wonderfully responsive, and on the off chance that you aren't sure you'll love it (you will) it'll be free to play at launch. I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

At first from looking at the screenshots, I thought this was another buggy, minecraft-esque voxel sandbox.

I was wrong.

I played it for a while, however it had one big flaw; it was almost featureless. I don't play Minecraft anymore, and honestly I never could really call it my favorite, however it still had a moderate amount of features. As a game developer and somewhat game player, through seeing things in past experience, this game is uncomparable in terms of features to many other games I've seen, as in it has VERY, VERY FEW. As in:

Chops Tree
Gets Cragwood
Makes big house in tree
Can't figure out what to do in house
Starts mining
Mines for 2 hours
Find corruption
Can't figure out what to do in the corruption
Gets diamonds

And then there's pretty much nothing left!

Another large issue that I see, is the CHILDLISHLY, COMPLETELY UNREALISTIC entities. While I in no way am in favor of the realism in Minecraft, at least it has COWS, and CHICKENS, and THINGS THAT DO NOT LOOK LIKE THEY CAME FROM A SHOW FOR LITTLE GIRLS, while in Creativerse, the same wth is this" message is constantly flitting through my head.
Plus
date:
it barely has any form of entity that is HOSTILE!

A leafy? What's a leafy?

I'm sorry

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Lets just talk about pros and cons here

Pros:
- Looks nice
- Interesting take on Voxel games
- Big open world
- Multiplayer
- Can visit other peoples worlds through the main screen

Cons:
- Combat is boring
- Biomes are simple and scattered
- Enemies are the same but different skins depending on biome
- Certain crafting materials are hard to find even for beginning recipes
- A store where you can buy blueprints/recipes is pointless
- Building is not as interesting as other Minecraft-esque games
- Need internet connection to play on single player

I tried this game hoping to see something cool with this genre but I was bored throughout playing this. I couldn't kill most creatures because you need to kill creatures to get the loot they drop to make better weapons and armor to kill them. I apparently reached the end of the world because my game just stopped loading in the map when I reached a certain point and was just a vast white emptiness. I'm not saying its unplayable or even that it doesn't have anything that might appeal to people but for me it just didnt really do anything different other than having strong visuals. Hopefully it will improve later on and I can like it more

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There aren't many games that you absoutely should play.

But you should play Creativerse.

A lot.

Everything about it is fun.  One action leads to a discovery, which suggests more actions.  Here's what happened when I started playing.  I pulled up a block and got a recipe to start crafting to find more recipes to get better armor to survive fighting the critters who have the ingredients to make the better sword to get the materials to make the better mining cell to get the ore to put in the forge to... what, it's 3 am already?  On TUESDAY?  But I still want to explore in those beautiful mountains!  And how big is that ocean I can see from here?

It's still early access, so they're updating frequently, but it's a solid game already and bugs are rare for me.  The devs' philosophy is that paid-for items should NOT be pay to play or pay to win.  There's nothing that you have to buy, only cool things you might like, and I really respect that.

If you like pretty games with crafting, building, exploring, mining, fighting monsters, taming monsters, exploring, demolishing, or farming, then....

You should play this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My feelings on this game are mixed and for that reason I will neither recommend it nor will I not recommend it. I'll leave that decision for those who decide to try the game.

The following is my Creativerse experience:

At first I was intrigued by it and wanted to see how it compared to other games similar to this that have come out since the creation of Minecraft. After playing for a bit I started to get a little more interested and thought it might be something I could have fun playing. I loved the idea of the blueprints system and was hoping to work towards building the fort some day. However I dont think I will be playing anymore after my short frustrating experience with the game. After gathering and crafting many materials I ended up losing everything after dying to a glowing crab that somehow managed to get into my safe room". I had finally found some obsidian and the extractors take 5 minutes to gather the ore. This of course being 5 real life minutes and the in-game clock ticks by much faster. Being a new player I hadn't had much chance to make the nicer gear which is what I was working towards. When I noticed it was getting close to night time I decided to build a little wall around myself so I could mine my ore in peace. Just as the exctractors where almost finished thats when that pesky crab came in and killed me. I don't know if it glitched through the wall I made or dug its way in but if it glitched its way in that bs needs to be fixed.


As a side note although at the beginning of my review I said I would neither recommend or not recommend the game becuase steam forces me to pick one inorder to post this review I am picking not recommend."
voteText: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Everything was so tedious.

You can't avoid damage from enemies, making getting armour difficult especially since there was no reliable way to heal. By the time i finished my last piece of leather armour, my first two pieces were pretty much destroyed. Being unable to avoid attacks also made taming a pain since you had to hold the bell on a creature for 20 seconds while everything in the immediate vacinity whaled on you.

Building a shelter required a lot of time and resources and night time creature are absolutely brutal. I was almost done my house by night fall and i died three times before day arrived and I finished my house. I was sitting in my house making more blocks when out of now where I died to a night pig. the second time I died was when I just killed the first one and a second one spawned behind me in my house. and the third time was when I ran around my house placing torches like a mad man (I think it was about 8-9 extra torches) and yet another pigsy spawned in my house and killed me. One other instance of brutal night creatures was when i was getting sand at dusk and the very second it became night three night rocksters spawned around me and murdered me.

I feel there are a lot of good ideas here but a lot of changes to how the game works are going to be necessary before this becomes a full game.
